The twelve dhÅ«tas are: First, not accepting people's invitations, going out for alms daily, and also not accepting a share of food and money from the bhiká¹£u saá¹ƒgha.
Second, staying overnight on the mountain, not staying in people's houses, towns, or villages.

Third, not begging for robes and bedding from others, and not accepting robes and bedding given by others, but only taking the discarded robes of dead people from the charnel ground to mend one's own robes.
Fourth, staying overnight in fields and under trees.
Fifth, eating only one meal a day, also called saá¹ƒkaká¹£ikÄ.
Sixth, not lying down day and night but only sitting, getting up to walk when sleepy, also called saá¹ƒghÄá¹­i.
Seventh, having three robes, no other clothes, and not sleeping in a quilt.
Eighth, they should stay in charnel grounds, not in Buddhist temples or among humans, and sit in meditation seeking the Way while gazing at the skeletons of the dead.
Ninth, they should only wish to stay alone and not see people, and also not wish to sleep with others.
Tenth, they should eat fruits and vegetables first and then eat rice, and after eating they should not eat fruits again.
Eleventh, they should only wish to sleep in the open air and not stay in tree groves or houses to sleep.
Twelfth, they should not eat meat or drink ghee, and sesame oil should not be applied to the body.
There are twenty-five things to keep in mind when carrying a staff:
First, it is for the sake of ground insects.
Second, it is for the sake of old age.
Third, it is for the sake of alms-begging.
Fourth, when entering and leaving while seeing a Buddha image, one should not make any sound with the head of the staff.
Fifth, one should not carry the staff into the assembly.
Sixth, after noon one should not carry the staff out again.
Seventh, one should not carry it on one's shoulder.
Eighth, one should not place it across the shoulders with the hands hanging on both sides.
Ninth, one should not shake it back and forth with the hands.
Tenth, one should not carry it to the back of the house.
Eleventh, if the three teachers have already left with the staff, one should not carry the staff and follow them out.
Twelfth, if four people are walking together and one person has left with the staff, one should not carry the staff and follow behind.
Thirteenth, when arriving at the donor's house, the staff should not be separated from the body.
Fourteenth, when arriving at someone's door, if one coughs three times and there is no response, one should leave and go elsewhere.
Fifteenth, if someone comes out, one should place the staff in the left elbow and hold it there.
Sixteenth, when the staff is in the room, it should not be placed on the ground.
Seventeenth, one should hold it close to one's bed.
Eighteenth, one should take it and wipe it.
Nineteenth, one should not allow it to grow moldy at the top.
20. If one wishes to carry a staff outside, one should receive it from a novice monk or a layperson.

21. When staying overnight in a sick person's home, one should be allowed to carry a staff in the evening.ğŸ”½22. When sending someone off far away, one should be allowed to carry a staff in the evening.
23. When going to stay overnight at a distant invitation, one should be allowed to carry a staff in the evening.
24. When going on an ÄcÄrya cloud, one should be allowed to carry a staff.
25. One should always keep it close to oneself, and should not point at people or draw characters on the ground.
There are five things to do when going to an upÄsaka's home:
1. When sent by the Saá¹…gha, 2. when begging for alms, 3. when on an ÄcÄrya cloud, 4. when invited to a meal, 5. when there is illness or death.

There are five things when a bhiká¹£u expounds the sÅ«tras to an upÄsikÄ:
1. If an upÄsikÄ comes to ask about the sÅ«tras while holding a small child, one should not expound with lustful thoughts.

Fourth, if an upÄsikÄ asks a bhiká¹£u to explain the sÅ«tra on the method of sesame oil, the man should hold a tooth stick and give it to the bhiká¹£u. If the bhiká¹£u holds the man's tooth stick, it is good and he should not explain.
Fifth, if an upÄsaka and an upÄsikÄ come together to ask about the sÅ«tra, if the upÄsaka leaves first, the bhiká¹£u should also leave. If not, it is not the Dharma.
There are ten virtues for a newly arrived bhiká¹£u:
First, after paying homage to the Buddha, he should step back and ask the karmadÄna about the family names of the bhiká¹£us, how many there are, and whose family name they hold on that day.

Third, he should not ask about the place of residence.
Fourth, if people give the bhiká¹£u a bed, seat, or bedding, he should not criticize it for being good or ugly.
Fifth, he should seek a preceptor to rely on.
Sixth, he should also make offerings.
Seventh, one should not criticize the sÅ«tras.

There are also five things:

First, one should be concerned about the affairs of the assembly; second, one should not use the pure water in the temple without reason; third, one should not go to people's doors without reason; fourth, one should not walk in the opposite direction; fifth, one should not jump over the temple's fences and trees.
One should treat the newly arrived bhiká¹£us with ten things:
First, one should avoid giving them a room.
Second, one should provide them with what they need.
Third, one should go to greet them in the morning and evening.
Fourth, one should tell them about the customs of the country.

Sixth, one should tell them where to beg for alms.
Seventh, one should tell them the rules taught by the Saá¹ƒgha.

If a newly arrived bhiká¹£u wishes to go to a virtuous one to take refuge and make him his preceptor, he should first say:
Now I am far from the three teachers, each of them is several li away.
Now I have come here alone. My original intention was to study, but I encountered unrest in the country, so I came here.
Now I take refuge in the virtuous one and ask him to be my preceptor.
Because the virtuous one accepts my refuge, he will accept me as a disciple. I will stay with him as a disciple and rely on him to live together as his disciple.
The virtuous one should use the Dharma to be my preceptor teacher.
Having bowed his head, he then says:
Preceptor!
For the sake of the Three Jewels, I have accepted so-and-so as my teacher. He will teach me the proper conduct for entering and leaving.
If anyone strongly disputes with so-and-so, the preceptor should act as so-and-so's disciple.
If the preceptor wishes to leave or stop, both are free to do so.
Even if so-and-so leaves and returns later, the preceptor should still accept so-and-so as a disciple.
Speak like this up to three times.
The teacher should say in reply:

Virtuous one so-and-so, listen now to what I say, which will enable you to attain the Way. You should always practice as the Buddha says, protect the precepts, be patient, be diligent, single-mindedly contemplate the Way, contemplate wisdom, stop the poisons of body, speech, and mind, and perform the three kinds of Dharma activities.
Having become a Buddha's disciple, you should not think of or engage in worldly matters.
Only those who practice in accordance with the Dharma will surely attain the Way and transcend the world.
Having spoken,
He should then rise, bow, place his head at the teacher's feet, return to get his robes and bowl, and go back to the teacher to receive the robes.
If a bhiká¹£u receives the robes and bowl, the preceptor bhiká¹£u should himself say that they were lost, destroyed by water, fire, thieves, or other causes.
The bhiká¹£u should first take refuge and say:
Virtuous One!
The pure precepts of wisdom practice are those of the three teachers.

For such and such, he should then recite the original causes and conditions three times, and after reciting three times, he should receive the preceptor's alms bowl or robes, and then give the admonitions:
Virtuous One, listen!
People have six faculties, which should be guarded and contemplated with purity.

Although worldly purity cannot reach purity, those who practice the path of wisdom should guard internal and external purity, neither defiled nor leaking, internally and externally corresponding, which is what can lead to the path of purity. Therefore, you should rely on it, embrace it, and guard it.
This is the matter of the almsbowl. Relying on it means to be told to hold it often, wear it often, and wash it in time.
Bhiká¹£us, it is like a wise one, also dwelling in the world, enjoying bathing, incense, clothing, bedding, and yet wanting to make the body uneasy and the mind uneasy.
All that is pleasing has broken garments.
Not arranging solid comfort.
Also unable to bring about the path of pure wisdom.
If it is wet with leaks and eaten by insects, it is like if one part of the body is rotten, then it is not comfortable and does not bring about the path of wisdom.
It is like if one part of the body is eaten by insects and has sores, whether painful or itchy, then it is not comfortable and does not bring about the path of wisdom.
From above to the end, relying on and protecting the inner and outer washing, this is to remove greed and have few desires, causing one to attain the purity of the wise one.
This is the matter of relying.
There are fifteen matters of relying on and following the instructions of the preceptor.
First, when the assembly of bhiká¹£us gathers, they should be taught to observe the hierarchy in accordance with the Dharma.
Second, the assembly of bhiká¹£us has instructions, telling them not to violate [the precepts].
Third, they should be taught to follow the hierarchy of the saá¹ƒgha.
Fourth, they should be taught to be respectful.
Fifth, they should be told about the taboos and customs of the various regions, what food should and should not be eaten.
Sixth, they should be told which places are suitable for begging and which are not.
Seventh, if there are thieves, they should be told which places to avoid and which to not avoid.
Eighth, if there are sick and weak [monks], they should be examined and cared for.
Ninth, if their robes are torn, they should be provided with [new ones].
Tenth, if there are those who wish to leave or stay, they should not be obstructed.
Eleventh, they should observe the intentions of others.
Twelfth, they should stay wherever it is convenient.
Thirteenth, if there are questions, they should be answered with humility.
Fourteenth, when watering the ground, they should always be humble.
Fifteenth, if there is a transgression, one should not say, I will no longer speak with you.
This is the method of relying on the ÄcÄrya.
There are five things for the disciple to rely on the ÄcÄrya:

First, one should go frequently; second, when arriving at the door, one should snap one's fingers three times; third, when entering, one should bow one's head; fourth, kneel for a long time and ask about the news; fifth, when leaving, one should return and leave through the door.
There are also five things:
First, visit in the morning and evening;
Second, when called by the teacher, put on the kasaya and respond, do not enter barefoot;
Third, sweep the ground, prepare water for washing, and wipe the bedding;
Fourth, if one has something to do oneself, or when coming and going, one should report;
Fifth, go to receive the sutra and ask about understanding, if one cannot, one should not have a fearful mind.
This is the five things, the method of relying on the ÄcÄrya oneself.
The wise bhiká¹£us should not keep seven kinds of medicine:

First, longevity-enhancing medicine, second, digestive medicine, third, emetic and purgative medicine, fourth, strong and moderate medicine, fifth, medicinal food, sixth, poison, and seventh, medicine for wounds from weapons.
If there is no illness, one should not take medicine, nor should one give it to others to take, and one will fall into an offense.
There are five things a bhiká¹£u should know when raising a novice:
First, he should know the Four Ä€gamas, second, he should know the precepts, third, he should know the sÅ«tras, fourth, he should have wisdom, and fifth, he should have virtue.

First, he should uphold the precepts, second, he should not violate the precepts, third, he should be able to understand the sÅ«tras, fourth, he should be patient, and fifth, he should guard himself in everything.

If a bhiká¹£u has a novice, he should teach him to practice five things:
First, if a novice monk is in the middle of doing something for the community, one should not call him to do something else;
Second, one should not let a novice monk seek the faults of a virtuous person;
Third, one should not believe the words of a novice monk;
Fourth, one should not scold a novice monk loudly in the assembly;
Fifth, one should not order a novice monk alone to do things, but should do them together with the community.
There are three things that one should not live with a novice monk:
First, if one likes him because he is handsome; second, if one wants to get angry when seeing him; third, if one is sick.
There are three things that one should expel:

First, if he says that violating precepts is not a crime; second, if he says that there is no Buddha, Dharma, or Sangha; third, if he goes to others and talks about the good and bad of his preceptor and teacher.
If one wants to travel far and entrust a novice monk to someone else, there are five things:
First, ask the novice monk if he is suitable for the other person;
Second, ask if he can serve the other person to their satisfaction;
Third, if the master scolds you, do not say, This is not my preceptor scolding me.
Fourth, serve the master as if serving me.
Fifth, if the master teaches you according to the Dharma, do not leave.
When bringing the novice monk to the master for entrustment, there are five things:
First, teach him to bow his head to the ground;
Second, teach him to take refuge;
Third, say, You should treat my novice monk as if he were your own novice monk;
Fourth, when I come back from there, he will return to me;
Fifth, if I am no longer here, he belongs to you permanently.
There are five things when accepting someone else's entrustment of a novice monk:

First, teach him to read sutras; second, teach him not to violate the precepts; third, teach him to follow the assembly in ascending and descending; fourth, teach him the rules of conduct; fifth, teach him to respect the people in the assembly.
There are five things when the bhiká¹£u assembly is having a meal:

First, when the senior monk has not yet sat down, one should not sit down first. Second, when the senior monk has not yet received the tray, one should not receive it first. Third, when the senior monk has not yet eaten, one should not eat first. Fourth, when the senior monk has not yet finished eating, one should not stop first. Fifth, when the senior monk has not yet gotten up, one should not get up first.
There are five things to do when receiving the tray:

First, one should receive it with a towel in hand. Second, it should be spread out to a width of six feet. Third, one should hold the towel connected to the tray or the leg of the table. Fourth, one should move back the knees. Fifth, the two elbows should not leave the knees.
There are also five things:
First, having received it, one should not leave.
Second, one should not look around wildly.
Third, having left, one should receive it from the senior monk.
Fourth, if someone is not suitable, one should not eat.
Fifth, if someone is not suitable, one should make a convenient arrangement oneself or call someone else.
There are also five things:

First, the left and right hands should not hold anything; second, one should not shout loudly to seek anything; third, when giving a bowl to others, one should look at the top and bottom to see if it is facing the other person; fourth, when giving a bowl, one should support the top with the right hand; fifth, one should protect what is received.
There are also five things:
First, when someone comes to give something, one should wash one's hands again after touching them;
Second, one should not put it directly into the bowl;
Third, if one sees something unpleasant, one should not eat it, and one should not let those around one know;
Fourth, one should not spit in front of the senior monk while eating;
Fifth, one should not eat what should not be eaten, and one will fall into a crime.
There are also five things:

First, one should not rub one's face with one's hands; second, one's left hand should not be close to one's right hand if it is dirty; third, if one's hands are dirty, one should not hold bowl water; fourth, one should not use one's dirty hands to straighten one's kasaya robe; fifth, one should not wipe one's greasy hands with a towel.
There are also five things:
First, if the bowl is placed horizontally in front, it should be straightened. If it is not straight, one should not eat.
Second, if food falls on the ground, one should not eat it again.
Third, if someone comes to offer something, one should always use one's finger to support it.
Fourth, if one does not see the person coming, one should not eat.
Fifth, while eating, one should not taste the flavors.
There are also five things:
First, while eating, one should not let out wind from the mouth.
Second, while eating, one should not spit on the ground in front.
Third, if one urgently wants to spit, spit on the ground below one's feet.
Fourth, after washing one's hands, one should not hold one's shoes again.
Fifth, if one realizes that one's hands are dirty after holding one's shoes, one should not hold one's kaá¹£Äya without wiping them.
To the right, there are forty matters regarding eating.
There are five things to do when washing and rinsing after a meal:

First, do not rub the bowl with your hands; second, do not use your fingers to pick your mouth; third, do not spit large amounts of mucus into the bowl; fourth, when rinsing your mouth, do not spit rice into the bowl; fifth, do not wave your hands around, splashing people on the left and right.
There are also five things:
First, when holding a towel, do not let it be soft, but should first thoroughly moisten it with your hands;
Second, do not shake it to dry it;
Third, do not use it to wipe your face, eyes, nose, or mouth;
Fourth, do not say I have my own and take it away without permission;
Fifth, use it according to the Dharma.
There are also five things:
First, when the towel is dry after wiping your hands, put it back on your lap;
Second, immediately put on your kaá¹£Äya, do not disturb people on the left and right;
Third, if the lower seat has not yet washed, do not scold them to come;
Fourth, when giving alms, do not speak nonsense;
Fifth, do not get up recklessly before the distribution of alms is finished.
There are also five rules:
First, if the senior monk is expounding the sutra for the donor, one should sit upright and listen;
Second, if one urgently needs to leave to do something, one should inform the monastery manager;
Third, if one urgently needs to go somewhere, one should tell the junior monks;
Fourth, if one receives money, one should immediately store it;
Fifth, if one needs to return something or entrust it to someone, one should not push it with one's foot, nor should one throw it to them from a distance.
There are ten rules for eating, and looking left and right without reason is a fault:ğŸ”½First, one should wait until the senior monk has received the food before eating;
Second, one should wait until the senior monk has all the utensils before eating;
Third, one should do the same for the junior monks;
Fourth, when everyone is eating, one should look again, and if the senior monk's food is running out, one should call for more;
Fifth, one should do the same for the junior monks;
Sixth, before the meal is finished, one should stop and observe what the senior monk wishes to have;
Seventh, observe the junior monks in the same way;
Eighth, observe whether the senior monk has finished or not. If one has finished first, one should hold the food in front with one's hands and not sit and watch others;
Ninth, observe the junior monks in the same way;
Tenth, one should not take the tray first, but should push it and hold it for others.
There are twenty-five rules for a bhiká¹£u holding a bhiká¹£aá¹‡abhÄjana bowl:ğŸ”½First, one should not hold the upper decoration with unclean hands;
Second, one should not hold the upper lid with unclean hands;

Fourth, one should not let others add water with unclean hands;
Fifth, one should not hold the front neck with unclean hands;
Sixth, one should support the belly from below;
Seventh, if there is little water, one should simply wash one's hands a little to make them clean;

Ninth, when wanting to add water, first pour water three times to wash and make it clean;

Twelfth, place it in a hidden place;
Thirteenth, the bottom should always have a branch;

23. If the hands are soiled while holding a basin, do not wipe the mouth with the upper part of the towel;
24. Do not use water from under the stove to wash the towel;
25. Wash the towel with water three times inside and out before using it.
When holding the towel to put it in the basin, do not throw it in with a loud sound.
There are five things to keep in mind when using a towel:
First, wipe the upper and lower head;
Second, use one end to wipe the hands and the other end to wipe the face and eyes;
Third, do not use it to wipe the nose;
Fourth, if it becomes soiled with oil, wash it immediately;
Fifth, do not wipe the body. If you are taking a bath, each person should have their own towel.
When putting on the saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robe, there are five things to keep in mind when holding the towel:

There are seven types of bhiká¹£us who should not be appointed as monastery superintendent or daily supervisor:

These seven types should not be appointed. If there are those who insist on appointing them, if they do not wish to do it, they should not be criticized or questioned.
This is the precious treasure of future generations.ğŸ”½Those who make clay bowls and serve as monastery superintendents should practice one hundred and sixty virtues.

Those who serve as monastery managers should practice thirty virtues.
The person in charge of the monastery's affairs should practice ten virtues:
These five people, if they practice as above, will soon attain the state of no-self and transcend the world.
The monastery's manager has fifteen virtues:
First, for the sake of the Buddha;
Second, for the sake of the Dharma;
Third, for the sake of the bhiká¹£u saá¹…gha;ğŸ”½Fourth, he should be frugal with the saá¹…gha's possessions;

There are also fifteen virtues in the property of the saá¹ƒgha:

Are you a monk?
One should wait until the next day.
Fourteenth, one should not sweep the cold and put it in the heat.
Fifteenth, one should not sweep the heat and put it in the cold.

The vihÄra master in charge of affairs, when serving meals in the hall, should practice twenty-five virtues:
First, after setting out the empty table, one should personally walk around and inspect below to see if everything is clean.
Second, one should not set out the empty table first.
Third, if the senior monk has received the distributed food.
Fourth, in all distributions, one should go to the novice monks or laypeople to receive.
Fifth, in the presence of the three teachers, one should not hold any increase or benefit.
Sixth, when dividing the food, make sure the portions are equal.
Seventh, when dividing the rice, do it yourself and make sure it is even.
Eighth, when dividing soup, stir it three times before serving.
Ninth, make sure the soup and rice are in balance.
Tenth, do not put the soup directly from the pot into people's bowls, but first divide it into another container.
Eleventh, do not talk or laugh while distributing the food.
Twelfth, do not shout from afar, saying, Bring so-and-so.
Thirteenth, if there are people in the assembly who do not eat soup, take what is convenient and give it to them.
Fourteenth, if there are people in the assembly who are incompatible with each other, do not scold them in the sitting area.
Fifteenth, be mindful of caring for the sick.
Sixteenth, when people bring things during the meal, distribute them all immediately, do not say you will save some for later.
Seventeenth, quickly serve the soup first.
Eighteenth, quickly serve the rice in the middle until it is all gone.
Nineteenth, one should not sit in the middle and look down on the monks.
Twentieth, one should not leave the monks and go out in front.
Twenty-first, after everyone has finished eating, one should check what is lacking and add more according to the amount.
Twenty-second, one should not stand and shout, asking people to collect the food and utensils.
Twenty-third, cover and store them without making noise, and discard them on the ground.
Twenty-fourth, one should instruct people to prepare brooms and water for washing hands in advance.
Twenty-fifth, one should stay and wait until the monks have finished the distribution, then one should announce the end and leave.
There are twenty-five virtues under the stove:
First, for the sake of the monks' bowls, one should endure with all one's strength.
Second, one should practice the Buddha's teachings with respect and regard everyone equally.
Third, if someone asks for something, if one has it, one should give it all, and one should not refuse by saying one does not have it.
Fourth, one should get up early and check if everything is ready.
Fifth, when using servants, if there is something to be bought, do not give it to beggars.
Sixth, if you want to call a servant, do not call out loudly from afar.
Seventh, when doing anything, do not make utensils with loud sounds.
Eighth, you should always be considerate of the people, do not act forcefully on your own.
